content: stuff lightly just enough to hold the shape use tail to close the hole then weave tail down through the bottom to use for sewing the shell to the body shell front/opening - this piece is worked in row 1 chain 8 single_crochet 6 single_crochet 5 into last chain single_crochet 6 back down opposite side 17 2 chain 1 turn half_double_crochet 2 single_crochet 5 single_crochet-increase x3 single_crochet 5 half_double_crochet 2 20 3 chain 1 turn half_double_crochet 4 single_crochet 12 half_double_crochet 4 20 4 chain 1 single_crochet 8 across the bottom 8 fo leave tail for sewing *your shell should have six distinct sides due to the increases the tail from the shell should be drawn through the middle of one side for sewing to the snail body this is now the bottom of the shell *to create the front of the shell you will sew the shell front/opening to the front your choice keeping the bottom as the bottom i held my finger under the front piece to keep it from being sewn on flat add a small amount of stuffing to help it hold its shape weave in ends *use tail from main shell piece to sew the shell to the top of the snail body i also added a few stitches securing the front shell edge to the body to keep in the little bit of stuffing i used *you can add a couple stitches to secure the head section to the body if you want i liked mine being loose when he s sitting flat the head is still held more upright my seymour was being added to a custom fugly monster though and needed to have his head secured in place a little bit you could also secure it by using a small amount of fabric glue i used stitches to be sure it would stay put
